review.title: Symbolic Music Data Version 1.0
review.abstract: In this document, we introduce a new dataset designed for training machine learning models of symbolic music data. Five datasets are provided, one of which is from a newly collected corpus of 20K midi files. We describe our preprocessing and cleaning pipeline, which includes the exclusion of a number of files based on scores from a previously developed probabilistic machine learning model. We also define training, testing and validation splits for the new dataset, based on a clustering scheme which we also describe. Some simple histograms are included.
histories: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.01368
review.COMMENTS: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.01368

metadata.title: Symbolic Music Data Version 1.0

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this appendix, we provide an overview of the symbolic music records we offer in pre-processed form1. Note that the source of four out of five of these records is the same set of midi files used in [BLBV12], which also provides pre-processed data. This work provided "piano roll" representations, which essentially consist of a regular temporal grid (period an eighth note) of on / off indicators for each midi note number. While piano roll is an excellent simplified music format for early studies of symbolic music modeling, it has several limitations, as discussed in previous work [Wal16]. To name such a limitation, the piano roll format does not explicitly represent the endings of notes and therefore cannot distinguish between, say, two consecutive eighth notes and a single quarter note. To address these limitations, we have extracted additional information from the same set of midi files.

sections.heading: 2 Preprocessing
sections.text: We have applied the following processing steps and filters to the raw midi data. • Combining piano "sustain pedal" signals with key information to obtain an equivalent individual note on / off events. • Removing duplicate / overlapping notes occurring on the same midi channel (although technically not allowed, this still occurs in real midi data due to the permissive nature of the midi file format). • Removing midi channels with less than two note events (these occurred in the MUS and CMA records and were always information tracks containing authoring information and receipts, etc. • Removing midi channels with fewer than two note events (these occurred in the MUS and CMA records and were always information tracks containing authoring information and receipts, etc.). • Removing midi channels with less than two note events likely to intersect with a previously occurring MMA file event.

sections.heading: 3 Splits
sections.text: The four sets of data used in [BLBV12] maintain the original training, testing and validation splits used in this work. For CMA, we took a cautious approach to data sharing. The main problem was data duplicates, since the midi archive provided to us contained several versions of several parts, each of which was slightly differently encoded by a different transcriptor. To reduce the statistical dependence between the traction, test and validation fragments of the CMA set, we used the following method: 1. We calculated a simple signature vector for each file consisting of the concatenation of two vectors, the first being the normalized histogram of the midi note numbers in the file. For the second vector, we quantified the event duration into a set of meaningful containers and calculated a normalized histogram of the resulting quantified duration.

sections.heading: 4 Basic Exploratory Plots
sections.text: Figures 2-5 provide some basic exploratory diagrams; note that the note distribution and number of notes per piece diagram is self-explanatory; note that the number of pieces per piece (bottom left) is set to one for the entire JSB dataset, due to a regrettable lack of midi-track information in these files, many of which are actually four-part harmonies; the pieces in the NOT dataset contain either one part (for pure melodies) or two (for melodies with accompanying chord accompaniments); the PMD dataset contains up to six parts (for a three-part Bach fugue, in which left and right hands are followed separately); MUS contains up to 27 parts (for Bach's Matthew Passion); and the CMA datasets contain two pieces with 46 voices - Ravel's Valses Nobles et Sentimentales and Venus, in which left and right hands are followed separately.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: Special thanks to Pierre Schwob of http: / / www.classicalarchives.com, who has allowed us to release the data in the form described by us.

referenceMentions.context: Note that the source of four out of five of these datasets is the same set of midi files used in [BLBV12], which also provides pre-processed data.
While the piano roll is an excellent simplified music format for early investigations into symbolic music modelling, it does have several limitations, as discussed in previous work [Wal16].

• Re-sampling of the timing information to a resolution of 2400 ticks per quarter note, as this is the lowest common multiple of the original midi file resolutions (see Table 1) for the four datasets considered in [BLBV12].
The score was computed by first training our model [Wal16] on the union of the four (transposed) datasets, JSB, PMD, NOT and MUS.
The four datasets used in [BLBV12] retain the original training, testing, and validation splits used in that work.
This leads to a similar ratio of split sizes as in [BLBV12].

metadata.abstractText: In this document, we introduce a new dataset designed for training machine learning models of symbolic music data. Five datasets are provided, one of which is from a newly collected corpus of 20K midi files. We describe our preprocessing and cleaning pipeline, which includes the exclusion of a number of files based on scores from a previously developed probabilistic machine learning model. We also define training, testing and validation splits for the new dataset, based on a clustering scheme which we also describe. Some simple histograms are included.
